In the first major move by the City of New Westminster, the city council has voted to scrap the National Bank Art Museum’s plan to tear down its former location on Royal Street and build a large new exhibition space in its place. The council voted 7–0 on Thursday to move the museum’s collection and research operations to the newly renovated building, which is slated to open in the spring of 2023.The decision means that the pieces in the museum’s collection will reside in the new building for the next fifty years. It also means that when the institution reopens in 2021, there will be two museums, one each in London and Vancouver, with the same permanent collection. The museum’s collection will be relocated to a temporary exhibition space at the new Royal Canadian Legion Hall, which is being constructed on the south side of the museum.According to the city, the new building will be capable of holding up to eight thousand artworks and will be designed in such a way that it will not only accommodate the museum’s collection and research activities, but also provide space for the public to visit the museum, including by appointment. The Shanghai Athenaeum, Shanghai’s largest arts institution, has appointed Peter Ding as its next director. Microsoft has released the first officially licensed works of the contemporary artist Kevin Beasley, a.k.a. Queer, an artist who blends media and performance to create a hybrid of surrealism and performance art. The artist was born in New York in 1962 and moved to the Bay Area in the late 1980s.Originally a painter in his early work, Beasley began using computers and video games to create works that blend the art of cinema, sculpture, and performance in ways that are often surreal, experimental, and conceptual. He has since shifted to creating more abstract artworks, often using materials he finds in his personal collection, and has been exhibited at numerous biennials, including the Venice Biennale (2010), the Houston International Film Festival (2013), and the San Francisco Museum of Art (2015).The Museum of Contemporary Art (MoCA), New York: The artist was awarded a Lifetime Achievement Award by the American Film Institute this week. In recognition of his achievements, the institute will offer $10,000 in prizes.
